instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.P3V3S0_EN: What is P3V3S0_EN? This signal enables the PP3V3_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> randomly not getting <SIGNAL>P3V3S0_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: This board is switching between 3.3V and 0V on <SIGNAL>P3V3S0_EN</SIGNAL> (from <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>).  It will work fine and the screen will come on and then next time I turn it on it will have no <SIGNAL>P3V3S0_EN</SIGNAL> (no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>) and <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> gets stuck at 1.9V. The only damage I can find was on the via leading to <RESISTOR>R8319</RESISTOR>. I fixed that. I replaced <CHIP>U8030</CHIP> just to rule that out. There are no shorts that I can find. Everything is measuring fine. Is this familiar at all? I'm not sure what's happening with this.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> randomly not getting <SIGNAL>P3V3S0_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Are you using original Magsafe 2 charger?
Don't use 1-->2 adapter.
Same thing on battery only?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> randomly not getting <SIGNAL>P3V3S0_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Yes, the same original 85W MagSafe 2 power adapter I always use.

I noticed that <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> does come up once every time I plug it in and drops down immediately.

I tried it with battery-only a number of times and it was turning on normally. But after going back to trying it on adapter-only, it's also working consistently now so I'm not sure it's telling me anything.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> randomly not getting <SIGNAL>P3V3S0_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
If <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> pulse only once, could be SMC sensor issue.
If starts to fail again, check if always starts in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> randomly not getting <SIGNAL>P3V3S0_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Any idea which sensor it might be? Or is it just possibly one of many? The only corrosion or damage was a little bit on the battery connector and near the keyboard backlight connector.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> randomly not getting <SIGNAL>P3V3S0_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
If you get pulse on all coils, then can be any Isense, or Vsense sensor.
Less probable to be temp sensor...
